posts.name: Clark Hillabrant
posts.cooked:
After doing some testing, I think our deadband is not being applied correctly. We have a pretty bad drifting problem. I made the deadband value = 0.95 to test if it is being applied. I honestly think it’s not, because of how normal the robot drove. Any drifting tips you have would be a huge help. Also, look at our code to see if anything looks funny, but I’m at a bit of a dead end. Also, we bought brand-new joysticks so that’s not the problem.

our code can be found on our GitHub here:

all the code used for the 2022-2023 season. Contribute to SHPRobotics/2022-Robot-Code development by creating an account on GitHub.

update, I have a pretty compelling fix for my problem however I need to update the code and test it. TLDR this line of code is used incorrectly: applyDeadband(leftSpeed, Constants.OperatorConstants.kDeadband); instead it should be this: leftFrontMotor.set(applyDeadband(frontLeftSpeedConstants.DriveTrainConstants.kdeaband));

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked:
Is the weight on the test chassis generally balanced?

Are the mecanums installed in the correct orientation (do the rollers make an X from the top of the robot and an O on the bottom of the robot?)

image 560×509 71 KB

image 560×509 71 KB

image 560×509 71 KB

Have you considered alternative options, such as the kit chassis?

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
I notice you’re applying the deadband to the four wheel speeds, after desaturation.  I think you would be better off applying it directly to the joystick inputs.

Consider using MathUtil.applyDeadband instead of rolling your own.  Consider also using the MecanumDrive class provided in WPILIB; among other things, it will do deadband for you.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: @Chilly How did that work out for you?

posts.name: Clark Hillabrant
posts.cooked: Using a joystick’s x axis for rotation solved all of the issues. The twist or z on the Logitech joys are really sensitive.

posts.name: mandrews281
posts.cooked:
We use the twist for yaw; and agree the Logitech twist axis is very sensitive.  So  we zero the twist UNLESS the trigger button is being held.  This gives us the best of both worlds (with and without twist driving).

mandrews281
